name: Robert Aderholt
misconductTexts: In 2010 Aderholt was investigated for keeping the difference between his requested travel per diems and the amount he actually spent. The House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct [recommended no further action](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-and-report-chair-and-ranking-republican-member-regarding-representatives).

misconductConsequences.action: recommended that the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct further review the allegations

misconductConsequences.body: House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct
misconductConsequences.action: recommended no further action

name: Sanford Bishop
misconductTexts: Rep. Bishop was investigated for spending both House office funds and campaign funds for personal use, including on annual holiday gatherings and tuition. The investigation [has been carried into the 118th Congress](https://www.congress.gov/117/crpt/hrpt706/CRPT-117hrpt706.pdf#page=+28). On Dec. 30, 2024, [the Committee announced](https://ethics.house.gov/press-releases/statement-of-the-committee-on-ethics-regarding-certain-investigative-matters-involving-allegations-of-personal-use-of-campaign-funds/) that while "there was evidence that the Member’s campaign did not fully comply with the applicable standards relating to personal use of campaign funds, as well as reporting or recordkeeping requirements for campaign expenditures", the member did not do so intentionally. The investigation has been ended.

misconductConsequences.action: continue an investigation based on an unpublished February 2020 referral from the Office of Congressional Ethics
published the Office of Congressional Ethics Report and Findings and the member's response
carried investigation into the 118th Congress
ended the investigation despite evidence that rules were violated

name: Vern Buchanan
misconductTexts: In 2012 Buchanan was investigated for improperly influencing a witness before the FEC and illegally reimbursing campaign contributors. The House Committee on Ethics concluded that there was insufficient evidence on the allegation of witness tampering, but that [the illegal reimbursements did occur, albeit without the representative's knowledge](https://www.congress.gov/114/crpt/hrpt643/CRPT-114hrpt643.pdf).

In 2011 Buchanan was investigated for failing to report positions he held with outside companies and to report unearned income from 2007 to 2010. The House Committee on Ethics [concluded that the representative unknowingly failed to disclose positions in outside companies and unearned income](https://www.congress.gov/112/crpt/hrpt588/CRPT-112hrpt588.pdf). They were satisfied when the representative amended his forms.

misconductConsequences.action: recommended that the Committee on Ethics further review the allegations
concluded that there was insufficient evidence on the allegation of witness tampering, but that the illegal reimbursements did occur, albeit without the Representative's knowledge
recommended that the Committee on Ethics further review the allegations
concluded that the representative unknowingly failed to disclose positions in outside companies and unearned income They were satisfied when the representative amended his forms

name: Judy Chu
misconductTexts: Rep. Chu was arrested in a protest at the Capitol on June 30, 2022. The House Committee on Ethics [released a report indicating she will pay the $50 fine](https://www.congress.gov/congressional-report/117th-congress/house-report/433/1?outputFormat=pdf&q=%7B%22search%22%3A%22ethics+chu%22%7D&s=7&r=1).

In 2017 Chu was investigated for having been arrested during a December protest outside of the White House. The House Committee on Ethics [recommended no action as the fine has been paid](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/DREAMER%20Protest%20Report_0.pdf).

In 2014 Chu received a letter of reproval for using House staff to perform campaign activities and then obstructing the investigation. The House Committee on Ethics concluded that the campaign work occured without her knowledge but because Chu attempted to obstruct the investigation, [a letter of reproval was issued](https://www.congress.gov/113/crpt/hrpt665/CRPT-113hrpt665.pdf).

misconductConsequences.action: reported that she will pay a $50 fine
recommended no action as the fine was paid
concluded that the campaign work occured without her knowledge but because Chu attempted to obstruct the investigation, a letter of reproval was issued

name: Yvette Clarke
misconductTexts: In 2015 Clarke was investigated for travel funded or organized by one or more entities prohibited from providing congressional travel. The House Committee on Ethics [concluded implicated House members did not intentionally accept gifts from prohibited entities](https://www.congress.gov/114/crpt/hrpt239/CRPT-114hrpt239.pdf).

misconductConsequences.action: recommended that the Committee on Ethics further review the allegation
concluded implicated House members did not intentionally accept gifts from prohibited entities

name: James Clyburn
misconductTexts: Rep. Clyburn was accused of [failing to complete security screening on April 20, 2021](https://ethics.house.gov/press-releases/statement-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-james) but on May 20, the House Committee on Ethics [agreed to Clyburn's appeal](https://ethics.house.gov/press-releases/statement-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-25).

misconductConsequences.action: began a review of Clyburn's appeal of his fine
agreed to Clyburn's appeal of his fine

name: Henry Cuellar
misconductTexts: Rep. Cuellar was indicted for allegedly accepting bribes from a Mexican bank and Azerbaijani oil company controlled by the nation's government. On May 29, 2024, the House Committee on Ethics [voted unanimously voted to establish an Investigative Subcommittee](https://ethics.house.gov/press-releases/statement-of-the-chairman-and-ranking-member-of-the-committee-on-ethics-regarding-representative-henry-cuellar/). In 2025, the Committee [reauthorized the Investigative Subcommittee for the 119th Congress](https://ethics.house.gov/press-releases/statement-of-the-chairman-and-ranking-member-of-the-committee-on-ethics-regarding-representative-henry-cuellar-2/). [In December 2025, President Trump pardoned Cuellar](https://www.politico.com/live-updates/2025/12/03/congress/henry-cuellar-pardon-reelection-party-00674518) even though he had so far only been indicted, but not tried or convicted, on charges of corruption.

misconductConsequences.action: indicted Rep. Cuellar
unanimously voted to establish an Investigative Subcommittee
reauthorized the Investigative Subcommittee for the 119th Congress

misconductConsequences.text: President Trump pardoned Cuellar even though he had so far only been indicted, but not tried or convicted, on charges of corruption.

misconductConsequences.action: recommended that the Committee on Ethics further review the allegation

name: Virginia Foxx
misconductTexts: Rep. Foxx [failed to complete security screening on May 13, 2021 and was fined $5,000](https://ethics.house.gov/press-releases/statement-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-24).

misconductConsequences.action: announced that Foxx had been fined by the Sergeant at Arms

name: Paul Gosar
misconductTexts: On Nov. 7, 2021, Rep. Gosar posted on his official social media accounts a video clip taken from the opening credits of an animated show called Attack on Titan. The clip was altered to add real people's faces to various characters. The result was a character with his face killing one with Rep. Ocasio-Cortez's face and flying at one, armed with swords, with President Biden's face. On Nov. 17, Rep. Gosar was [censured](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/117/hres789/text) and removed from his committee assignments (one of which he shared with Rep. Ocasio-Cortez) by a vote of [223-207](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/117-2021/h379).

In February 2018, a resolution to reprimand Rep. Gosar for attempting to pressure Capitol Police via Twitter to arrest State of the Union 2018 guests he described as "illegal aliens" [was tabled (i.e. failed) on party lines, 231-187](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/115-2018/h53). Several Democratic representatives brought undocumented immigrants who are currently part of the DACA program to the speech.

misconductConsequences.text: Rep. Gosar posted the video clip.

misconductConsequences.action: censured Rep. Gosar and removed him from committee assignments

misconductConsequences.text: Asked Capitol Police to arrest DACA recipients attending the 2018 State of the Union address.

misconductConsequences.action: tabled resolution of reprimand, 231-187

name: Sam Graves
misconductTexts: In 2009 Graves was investigated for inviting improper hearing witnesses. The House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct [dismissed the charges as Representative Graves did not act improperly](https://www.congress.gov/111/crpt/hrpt320/CRPT-111hrpt320.pdf).

misconductConsequences.action: recommended the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct further review the allegations

misconductConsequences.body: House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct
misconductConsequences.action: dismissed the charges as Representative Graves did not act improperly

name: Al Green
misconductTexts: At the President's Joint Address to Congress on March 4, Rep. Green repeatedly objected to various statements by the President. He was removed from the chamber and on March 6, he was censured [224-198](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/119-2025/h62).

In August 2021, Rep. Green was arrested at a protest. In September 2021, the House Committee on Ethics reported that a fine was paid and [closed the investigation](https://ethics.house.gov/press-releases/statement-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-al).

misconductConsequences.action: censured Rep. Green 224-198
reported the arrest and that a fine was paid, and closed the investigation

name: Andy Harris
misconductTexts: Rep. Harris was accused of [attempting to carry a concealed firearm onto the House floor on January 21, 2021](https://www.huffpost.com/entry/house-congressman-gun-andy-harris_n_600a0874c5b674575ae423ae?gjl). That [the Capitol Police were investigating](https://www.huffpost.com/entry/capitol-police-investigate-member-incidents-metal-detectors-house-chamber_n_602dd485c5b67c32961b2d8e?aod) became public when they interviewed a Huffington Post reporter who'd witnessed the event as part of the investigation.

misconductConsequences.action: interviewed a Huffington Post reporter who'd observed and reported the incident being investigated

name: Bill Huizenga
misconductTexts: Rep. Huizenga failed to complete a security screening prior to entering the House Chamber on August 23, 2021. In October 2021, the House Committee on Ethics agreed to Huizenga's appeal of the fine.

In 2019, Huizenga was accused of accepting campaign contributions from staff and making improper campaign expenditures. In August that year, the Office of Congressional Ethics [recommended further review](https://oce.house.gov/reports/investigations/oce-referral-regarding-rep-bill-huizenga) by the House Committee on Ethics. In 2024, the Committee [closed the matter](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/documents/Committee%20Report_58.pdf) saying "Based on the totality of the circumstances, including the lack of any clear pattern of misspending or intentional circumvention of any standards of conduct, as well as Representative Huizenga’s consistent cooperation with this review, the significant remedial steps that his campaign has undertaken, and the widespread need for updated guidance on the personal use of campaign funds, the Committee determined that Representative Huizenga’s conduct did not merit a sanction."

misconductConsequences.action: fined Rep. Huizenga $5,000 for failing to complete a security screening prior to entering the House Chamber on August 23, 2021
announced the fine
agreed to the appeal
recommended further review by the House Committee on Ethics
published the Office of Congressional Ethics Report
carried the investigation into the 118th Congress

issued a report with no sanctions, new guidance for all members and a private letter to the member after finding that some expenditures fell into a gray area and that the member's reporting could have been better

misconductConsequences.action: reported the arrest and that he paid the fine, and closed the investigation

name: Mike Kelly
misconductTexts: Rep. Mike Kelly is accused of making a stock purchase, through his wife, based on nonpublic information he learned in his official duties. The Committee [carried its investigation into the 118th Congress](https://www.congress.gov/117/crpt/hrpt706/CRPT-117hrpt706.pdf#page=+33). In 2025, the Committee [released its report](https://ethics.house.gov/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/20250725-Committee-Report.pdf) finding that Kelly did not violate rules related to insider trading and conflicts of interest.

misconductConsequences.action: recommended further review by the House Committee on Ethics
extended its investigation

name: Michael McCaul
misconductTexts: Rep. McCaul was [detained on suspicion of public drunkenness at Dulles International Airport](https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/congress/republican-rep-michael-mccaul-detained-police-alcohol-airport-rcna180028) on November 4, 2024. He was not charged and said he had [combined Ambien with "several alcoholic drinks"](https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/congress/republican-rep-michael-mccaul-detained-police-alcohol-airport-rcna180028). Rep. McCaul is chair of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. On Dec. 23, 2024, [the Committee released their report](https://ethics.house.gov/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/Committee-Report-1.pdf) indicating that Rep. McCaul said the charges had been dropped and the Committee was therefore closing the investigation

misconductConsequences.action: detained on suspicion of public drunkenness at Dulles International Airport

name: Gregory Meeks
misconductTexts: In 2015 Meeks was investigated for travel funded or organized by one or more entities prohibited from providing congressional travel. The House Committee on Ethics [concluded implicated House members did not intentionally accept gifts from prohibited entities](https://www.congress.gov/114/crpt/hrpt239/CRPT-114hrpt239.pdf).

In 2011 Meeks was investigated for failing to disclose a gift in 2007 and receiving a loan on terms not available to the general public in 2010. The House Committee on Ethics dismissed the loan allegation, but found the representative [unknowingly failed to properly disclose the gifts](https://www.congress.gov/112/crpt/hrpt709/CRPT-112hrpt709.pdf).

name: David Schweikert
misconductTexts: In 2018, Rep. Schweikert was accused of using or authorizing impermissable expenditures from his Members’ Representational Allowance and receiving improper campaign contributions. In June 2018, the House Committee on Ethics [established an Investigative Subcommittee (ISC)](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-chairwoman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-19). In December of 2018, the ISC [expanded its investigation](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-chairwoman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-28) and added alleged failure to make financial disclosures. On July 30, 2020, the House Committee on Ethics published their report, [concluded he was guilty of all charges](https://www.congress.gov/congressional-report/116th-congress/house-report/465), recommended a reprimand and fined Schweikert $50,000. On July 31, 2020, the [House voted unanimously](https://www.washingtonpost.com/powerpost/house-votes-to-reprimand-gop-rep-schweikert-for-11-ethics-violations/2020/07/31/2490303e-d327-11ea-9038-af089b63ac21_story.html) in a voice vote to formally reprimand Rep. Schweikert.

misconductConsequences.action: established an Investigative Subcommittee

misconductConsequences.body: House Committee on Ethics Investigative Subcommittee
misconductConsequences.action: expanded the inquiry into more instances of improper uses of funds and to add allegations of failure to provide financial disclosures
published the Office of Congressional Ethics report as required when the Investigative Subcommittee has not completed its work one year after its establishment
reauthorized for the Investigative Subcommittee for the 116th Congress
published their report, concluded he was guilty of all charges, recommended a reprimand and fined Schweikert $50,000
voted unanimously by voice to reprimand Rep. Schweikert

name: Russ Fulcher

Fulcher was accused of assaulting a Capitol Police officer when [refusing to fully comply with security procedures before entering the House floor on January 12, 2021](https://www.huffpost.com/entry/capitol-police-investigate-member-incidents-metal-detectors-house-chamber_n_602dd485c5b67c32961b2d8e?aod). name: Jesús García
misconductTexts: [Rep. Garciá chose to time his retirement announcement until after his preferred successor had submitted her own petition to get on the primary ballot](https://www.politico.com/live-updates/2025/11/18/congress/chuy-garcia-ballot-petitions-00656890) and near the deadline for submitting petitions to be on the ballot. The end result is that his preferred successor is now the only person in 2026 Democratic primary for his seat. Another Democratic representative, Rep. Gluesenkamp Perez (D-WA3) filed a resolution of disapproval which passed [236-183](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/119-2025/h292).

misconductConsequences.action: approved a resolution of disapproval 236-183

In July 2020, the House Committee on Ethics [published its report dismissing the charges](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/documents/Committee%20Report_17.pdf) since the alleged excessive contributions were part of joint holdings with her spouse and any reporting errors were unintentional.

name: Rashida Tlaib
misconductTexts: In Nov. 2023, Rep. Tlaib was [censured 234-188](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/118-2023/h622) for promoting false narratives regarding the October 7, 2023, Hamas attack on Israel and for calling for the destruction of the state of Israel.
Tlaib was arrested at a protest in front of the U.S. Supreme Court building on July, 19 2022. The same month the Committee published a committee report indicating they will pay a $50 fine.

In 2019, Tlaib was accused of reporting improper campaign expenditures. In August, the Office of Congressional Ethics [recommended further review](https://oce.house.gov/reports/investigations/oce-referral-regarding-rep-rashida-tlaib) by the House Committee on Ethics. In November, the House Committee on Ethics [published the Office of Congressional Ethics Report and Findings and Tlaib's response](https://ethics.house.gov/press-releases/statement-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-5). In August 2020, the House Committee on Ethics found that while Rep. Tlaib did receive campaign funds for personal use after the 2018 general election, it was an error and not malfeasance. She is fined $10,800, the amount she received after the election.

misconductConsequences.action: censured 234-188
published a committee report indicating they will pay a $50 fine
recommended further review by the House Committee on Ethics
published the Office of Congressional Ethics Report and Findings and the member's response
fined Rep. Tlaib $10,800, the amount of campaign funds she received after the election and concluded that it was an error, not malfeasance

name: Ilhan Omar
misconductTexts: Omar was arrested at a protest in front of the U.S. Supreme Court building on July, 19 2022. The same month the Committee published a committee report indicating they will pay a $50 fine.

In 2021, Rep. Omar was accused of ommitting required financial disclosures and accepting an advance on her memoir. The Office of Congressional Ethics [voted unanimously in December 2021 to recommend that the House Committee on Ethics dismiss the case](https://oce.house.gov/reports/investigations/oce-report-regarding-rep-ilhan-omar) for lack of evidence. In 2022, two of the four House Committee on Ethics members did not vote to dismiss, but House rules have no guidelines for how to proceed in this situation so [no further action will be taken](https://ethics.house.gov/press-releases/statement-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-ilhan/).

misconductConsequences.action: published a committee report indicating they will pay a $50 fine

did not dismiss the case because a majority did not agree to that, but will not pursue further action based on the Office of Congressional Ethics recommendation

name: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez
misconductTexts: The House Office of Congressional Ethics found "substantial reason to believe" that Ocasio-Cortez accepted impermissible gifts associated with her attendance at the Met Gala in 2021, which she paid for after the investigation began. In 2025, the House Committee on Ethics [published its report finding that while Ocasio-Cortez tried to accurately assess the value of the items received and pay in advance, the amounts were too low and she was assessed to owe additonal sums to the vendors involved](https://ethics.house.gov/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/Committee-Report-20250725-Rep.-Ocasio-Cortez-1.pdf).
Ocasio-Cortez was arrested at a protest in front of the U.S. Supreme Court building on July, 19 2022. The same month the Committee published a committee report indicating they will pay a $50 fine.

name: Andrew Clyde
misconductTexts: Since 2021, Rep. Clyde was fined many times for failing to wear a mask on the House floor during the COVID-19 pandemic. The Rep. appealed his fines several times, but all have been denied. With a $500 fine for the first time and a $2,500 fine for each subsequent time, it is believed that, as of June 2022, Clyde has been fined at least $103,000, taken out of his congressional salary.

Rep. Clyde [failed to complete security screening on February 3, 2021 and was fined $5,000](https://ethics.house.gov/press-releases/statement-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-20). On April 12, the [Committee rejected Clyde's appeals](https://ethics.house.gov/press-releases/statement-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-23).

name: Victoria Spartz
misconductTexts: Rep. Spartz was charged with a [misdemeanor weapons violation at Dulles Airport](https://apnews.com/article/indiana-congresswoman-victoria-spartz-airport-firearm-charged-c0684e073b347f8ee5499c12675dc292) on June 28 when an unloaded handgun was found in her carry on luggage during security screening. Charges were dismissed in September 2024 when Rep. Spartz completed a gun safety training course. The House Committee on Ethics [issued its report and closed the investigation](https://www.congress.gov/118/crpt/hrpt731/CRPT-118hrpt731.pdf) in November 2024.

In May 2022, the House Committee on Ethics [published the Office of Congressional Ethics Report and Findings and Fallon's response](https://ethics.house.gov/press-releases/statement-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-pat-0). In July of 2022, the Committee unanimously voted to dismiss the referral.

name: Ronny Jackson
misconductTexts: In 2022, the House Ethics Committee announced an investigation into possible campaign finance violations because Rep. Jackson used campaign funds to pay for membership at an Amarillo social club. In June of 2024, the House Ethics Committee announced an apparent second separate investigation (that was subsequently combined with the first one) since the Office of Congressional Ethics [issued a second report recommending further review by House Ethics](https://oce.house.gov/reports/investigations/oce-referral-regarding-rep-ronny-jackson-0) on the same topic because Rep. Jackson has continued to use campaign funds all this time to pay the Amarillo Club. On Dec. 30, 2024, [the Committee announced](https://ethics.house.gov/press-releases/statement-of-the-committee-on-ethics-regarding-certain-investigative-matters-involving-allegations-of-personal-use-of-campaign-funds/) that while "there was evidence that the Member’s campaign did not fully comply with the applicable standards relating to personal use of campaign funds, as well as reporting or recordkeeping requirements for campaign expenditures", the member did not do so intentionally. The investigation has been ended.

misconductConsequences.action: recommended further review by the House Committee on Ethics
extended the matter regarding the representative

name: Blake Moore
misconductTexts: In July 2021, Rep. Moore violated the STOCK Act by failing to meet a financial disclosure deadline and [paid a fine](https://www.sltrib.com/news/politics/2021/07/26/this-utah-congressman/).

name: Sheila Cherfilus-McCormick
misconductTexts: Rep. Cherfilus-McCormick was indicted by the Department of Justice in 2025 for violating campaign finance laws by [using overpayments to her business from COVID-era progams for her 2022 congressional campaign](https://www.huffpost.com/entry/sheila-cherfilus-mccormick-indicted-fema-funds_n_691e5d0fe4b0b763ab8dace8). She has been under investigation since 2023 by the Office of Congressional Ethics and the House Committee on Ethics for that as well as allegations of failing to properly disclose required information on statements required to be filed with the House and accepting voluntary services for official work from an individual not employed in her congressional office. In 2024, the Ethics Committee [expanded the investigation](https://ethics.house.gov/press-releases/statement-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-85) to include new allegations in a 2024 Office of Congressional Ethics report not yet made public that Cherfilus-McCormick was engaging in improper conduct in connection with community project funding requests; misusing official funds for campaign purposes; and/or violating campaign finance laws and regulations in connection with her 2024 re-election campaign.

misconductConsequences.action: recommended further review by the House Committee on Ethics of allegations in a report not made public until 2024
extended the matter
established an Investigative Subcommittee and released a summary of the allegations
expanded the jurisdiction of the Investigative Subcommittee to include new allegations from a 2024 Office of Congressional Ethics report not yet made public
released the Office of Congressional Ethics' 2023 report
reauthorized the Investigative Subcommittee for the 119th Congress
indicted for keeping overpayments from COVID era progams and then using the extra money to fund her 2022 Congressional campaign

name: Cory Mills
misconductTexts: The House Committee on Ethics opened a new investigation on Mills after the House voted [310-303](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/119-2025/h302) to refer a [resolution of censure](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/119/hres893/text) to the House Ethics Committee over a range of allegations, some of which were already being investigated. New allegations include a dispute over Mills's claims of holding a Bronze Star for his military service. In January 2026, the Committee established an [Investigative Subcommittee with members Garbarino, Subramanyam, Yakym and Pressley](https://ethics.house.gov/press-releases/statement-of-the-chairman-and-ranking-member-of-the-committee-on-ethics-regarding-representative-cory-mills-3/).

On Feb. 19, 2024, Rep. Mills assaulted a woman in his home. The Metropolitan D.C. Police were called to the scene. The police have issued several reports on the incident, in increasingly less detail each time. The first report indicated that the victim said she was assaulted by Mills and she let police listen to a conversation with him in which he encouraged her to lie to the police. Subsequent reports have much less detail. An internal investigation of the handling of the matter is underway. An arrest warrant sent to the U. S. Attorney has not yet been signed. In October 2025, [a judge issued a restraining order against Mills](https://www.politico.com/news/2025/10/14/cory-mills-restraining-order-florida-00608307) to protect a different ex-girlfriend who broke up with him when the news of the above alleged assault became public. A [resolution to censure Mills](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/119/hres893/text) for this and other conduct was referred to the House Committee on Ethics in November 2025.

Rep. Mills was accused of ommitting or misrepresenting contributions to his campaign in financial disclosure documents, benefiting from federal contracts while in office and failing to properly disclose that as well, according to an August 2024 [Office of Congressional Ethics report](https://ethics.house.gov/wp-content/uploads/2025/03/OCC-Report-and-Findings.pdf) which was made public in 2025. A [resolution to censure Mills](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/119/hres893/text) for this and other conduct was referred to the House Committee on Ethics in November 2025.

misconductConsequences.action: voted 310-303 to refer a resolution of censure to the House Ethics Committee
opened an investigation and will be establishing an Investigative Subcommittee

name: Mike Collins
misconductTexts: In January 2026, [the House Committee on Ethics announced it was publishing the Office of Congressional Conduct (OCC) referral in the case of Rep. Mike Collins](https://ethics.house.gov/press-releases/statement-of-the-chairman-and-ranking-member-of-the-committee-on-ethics-regarding-representative-mike-collins-2/). The OCC found substantial reason to believe that Rep. Collins had been using Congressional resources for unofficial or otherwise unauthorized purposes, retaining an employee who did not perform duties commensurate with the compensation received, and dispensing special favors or privileges by employing a district intern who had a preexisting personal romantic relationship with the office chief of staff and who did not perform duties commensurate with her compensation.

misconductConsequences.action: announced it was publishing the Office of Congressional Conduct (OCC) referral in the case of Rep. Mike Collins

name: Andrew Ogles
misconductTexts: In 2024, Rep. Ogles was accused of falsifying campaign finance reports when his amended finance reports were compared to the originals. He claimed he had loaned his campaign $320,000 in 2022 and had not. It's unclear whether the the money came from elsewhere or was entirely made up. He also amended finance reports to remove both contributions and expenditures. In the first week of August, 2024, a Department of Justice search was conducted and his cell phone seized. The House Ethics Committee began an investigation in 2024 and extended the matter into the 119th Congress.

misconductConsequences.action: executed a search warrant and seized Rep. Ogles' phone
recommended further review by the House Committee on Ethics
published the OCE report

name: Wesley Hunt
misconductTexts: In 2024, the Office of Congressional Ethics recommended further review by the House Committee on Ethics on the allegation that Rep. Hunt had converted campaign funds to personal use by using them to pay for membership in a social club. On Dec. 30, 2024, [the Committee announced](https://ethics.house.gov/press-releases/statement-of-the-committee-on-ethics-regarding-certain-investigative-matters-involving-allegations-of-personal-use-of-campaign-funds/) that while "there was evidence that the Member’s campaign did not fully comply with the applicable standards relating to personal use of campaign funds, as well as reporting or recordkeeping requirements for campaign expenditures", the member did not do so intentionally. The investigation has been ended.

misconductConsequences.action: recommended further review by the House Committee on Ethics
published the OCE report and the representative's response
ended the investigation despite evidence that rules were violated

name: Thomas Suozzi

In July of 2022, the Committee unanimously voted to dismiss the referral.

misconductConsequences.action: recommended further review by the House Committee on Ethics
extended the matter regarding the representative
dismissed the referral

name: LaMonica McIver
misconductTexts: On May 9, 2025, [Newark Mayor Ras Baraka was handcuffed and arrested](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/06/03/nyregion/ras-baraka-alina-habba-lawsuit-ice.html) while standing outside of an Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) detention center in Newark. He had been waiting on three members of Congress to finish their inspection of the facility. When they came back out and ICE began to try to arrest him, the Congress members tried to block ICE from doing so. They did not succeed, but the charges were dropped a few hours later. Nonetheless, one of the members of Congress, [Rep. McIver, has been charged with assaulting, impeding, and interfering with law enforcement](https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/rep-lamonica-mciver-charged-doj-incident-ice-agents/story?id=121971746) because she pushed against ICE officers in body armor with her unarmored arms.

misconductConsequences.action: charged Rep. McIver with assaulting, impeding, and interfering with law enforcement

name: Marlin Stutzman
misconductTexts: In 2016 Stutzman was investigated for using campaign funds for a 2015 family trip which included some campaign activity. The House Committee on Ethics recommended further review; however after Stutzman's loss in the 2016 election, [the investigation was ended](https://www.congress.gov/114/crpt/hrpt910/CRPT-114hrpt910.pdf#page=+34).

misconductConsequences.action: recommended that the Committee on Ethics further review the allegation
published the Office of Congressional Ethics Report and Findings and Rep. Stutzman's response.
reported that election loss ended the committee's jurisdiction.
